channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Abuse report police chief to stay
item.description: The Police and Crime Commissioner for South Yorkshire vows to stay in the job despite calls for him to quit over a damning report into child abuse in Rotherham.

item.title: IS accused of Syria mass atrocities
item.description: The UN accuses IS militants of war crimes, and the Syrian government of using chemical agents in eight separate incidents in a new report.

item.title: IMF's Lagarde under investigation
item.description: IMF head Christine Lagarde says she has been placed under formal investigation for negligence in a French fraud case but has not been charged.

item.title: US girl, nine, kills gun instructor
item.description: A nine-year-old girl kills her shooting instructor by accident while being shown how to use an Uzi submachine gun at a firing range in Arizona.

item.title: Ukraine rebels enter coastal town
item.description: Pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine push their way into the port of Novoazovsk, threatening to open up a new front in the war.

item.title: Nigeria closes schools over Ebola
item.description: Nigerian schools are ordered to remain shut, delaying the new academic year until 13 October as part of measures to prevent the spread of Ebola.

item.title: RBS fined £14.5m over mortgage advice
item.description: Royal Bank of Scotland is fined £14.5m by the Financial Conduct Authority for failing to ensure that it gave suitable mortgage advice to customers.

item.title: Swinney says 'No currency, no debt'
item.description: Finance secretary John Swinney has confirmed Scotland will not pay its share of the UK debt if it does not get a currency union after independence.

item.title: Freed US journalist returns home
item.description: American journalist Peter Theo Curtis, freed two days ago after nearly two years in captivity in Syria, arrives back in the US.

item.title: Brown and Darling in referendum call
item.description: Gordon Brown appears alongside his former chancellor Alistair Darling to call on Scottish voters to reject independence.

item.title: Met chief backs 'new control orders'
item.description: Measures similar to control orders should be re-introduced to tackle the threat from Britons who fight with militants in Syria and Iraq, the UK's most senior police officer has said.

item.title: Call for Facebook beheadings rethink
item.description: Controversial beheading photo posts from Syria spur one of Facebook's safety advisers to call for pictures to have warnings.

item.title: VIDEO: Kate Bush fans: 'Worth the wait'
item.description: Delighted fans took to their feet at London's Hammersmith Apollo to applaud Kate Bush, as she closed her first concert in 35 years on Tuesday night.

item.title: VIDEO: Cheryl and Cowell back to take on Strictly
item.description: The new series of the X Factor is back on television screens from Saturday. Colin Paterson looks at the new judging line-up and the future of the show

item.title: VIDEO: Phones to come with 'kill switch'
item.description: A new law has been passed meaning that smartphones in California will be required to come with a "kill switch" to render them useless if lost or stolen.

item.title: VIDEO: How sheepdogs control unruly flocks
item.description: A farmer explains his relationship with his sheepdog, after researchers help unravel the mystery of how the animals do their job.

item.title: AUDIO: Lottery winner's ticket bin hunt
item.description: A woman who won £1m on a lottery scratchcard had an anxious wait while a shop assistant looked through a bin for the missing corner of their winning ticket.

item.title: VIDEO: India's iconic Ambassador car
item.description: Sanjoy Majumder reports on the passing of one of India's best known and trusted icons, the Ambassador.

item.title: AUDIO: MK Dons thrash Man Utd 4-0
item.description: Louis van Gaal's miserable start to life as Manchester United boss has continued with a Capital One Cup shock at the hands of League One MK Dons.

item.title: VIDEO: How much oil does Scotland have?
item.description: Campaigns on both sides of the Scottish independence discussion have been contesting exactly how much oil Scotland might have left in the North Sea.

item.title: Couple celebrate 80 years of marriage
item.description: A couple who met as teenagers 10 years before the start of World War Two celebrate their 80th wedding anniversary.

item.title: Woman finds 3ft wasp nest on bed
item.description: A Hampshire pest controller takes on the "biggest job of his career", after being called to deal with a nest of more than 5,000 wasps.

item.title: Button's McLaren career uncertain
item.description: Jenson Button's Formula 1 career is in doubt as his team McLaren continue their pursuit of Ferrari's Fernando Alonso.

item.title: Warnock named Crystal Palace boss
item.description: Crystal Palace appoint former boss Neil Warnock as their new manager on a two-year deal after choosing him ahead of Steve Clarke.

item.title: Celtic pay penalty for downsizing
item.description: BBC Scotland's Tom English reviews Celtic's Champions League play-off exit at the hands of NK Maribor.

item.title: VIDEO: BBC Sport's A-Z of summer: Part two
item.description: Watch part two of BBC Sport's A-Z of summer, featuring Usain Bolt's antics at the Commonwealth Games and Germany's superb World Cup win.

item.title: Hodgson set to name England captain
item.description: Roy Hodgson is set to announce his new England captain on Thursday - with Wayne Rooney favourite for the role.

item.title: Supermarket growth 'at 10-year low'
item.description: Low inflation in the price of groceries has led to growth in supermarket sales hitting a 10-year low, according to research firm Kantar Worldpanel.

item.title: VIDEO: Scots independence: Business views
item.description: Two business chief executives give their opinions on whether independence would be good for Scotland's businesses.

item.title: Anti-independence firms make case
item.description: A letter signed by 130 firms says the business case for independence “has not been made”.

item.title: VIDEO: Scotland Decides: Referendum Today
item.description: Sarah Smith presents Scotland Decides: Referendum Today, a programme looking at the issues around the Scottish Independence Referendum.

item.title: Tomatoes linked with fighting cancer
item.description: Eating tomatoes may lower the risk of prostate cancer, research suggests.

item.title: VIDEO: Cellist: 'Alcohol was my medicine'
item.description: Cellist Rachael Lander talks about how she secretly used alcohol and beta-blockers to get through concerts and her eventual road to recovery.

item.title: Primary school places budget squeeze
item.description: There are warnings that the rising primary school population in England is putting pressure on budgets and raising fears of "supersize" schools.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Trojan horse' principal on school return
item.description: A principal at an academy school in Birmingham, who resigned because she felt under undue pressure from governors, has given a statement after resuming her post.

item.title: Star Trek X Prize finalists named
item.description: Ten groups have been chosen as finalists in a $10m (£6m) competition to develop a real-life "tricorder" - the medical scanner used in Star Trek.

item.title: Concerns grow over Iceland volcano
item.description: Overnight earthquakes raise fears that magma from Iceland's Bardarbunga volcano could be heading towards another large volcanic system, scientists say.

item.title: VIDEO: How sheepdogs control unruly flocks
item.description: A farmer explains his relationship with his sheepdog, after researchers help unravel the mystery of how the animals do their job.

item.title: Fans' delight at Kate Bush comeback
item.description: Kate Bush makes her stage comeback at London's Hammersmith Apollo to an ecstatic response from fans at her first live concert for 35 years.

item.title: The drunken monkey that smashed up a bar
item.description: Author Jeremy Clay tells the story of a monkey that went on a drunken rampage.

item.title: Politicians and their shipping containers
item.description: Why Pakistani political hopefuls have to have their own shipping containers - often customised at some expense.

item.title: 'Horrific betrayal' - abuse scandal on front pages
item.description: Findings that at least 1,400 children were subjected to appalling sexual exploitation in Rotherham between 1997 and 2013 lead most papers.

item.title: Man stabbed to death during fight
item.description: A 24-year-old man is stabbed to death in Croydon during a fight among a group of males.

item.title: Funeral for Borneo murder victim
item.description: Hundreds of mourners pack a Derbyshire church for the funeral of a student stabbed to death in Borneo.

item.title: Sturgeon predicts Shetland oil boom
item.description: Shetland is on the cusp of a "second oil boom", the deputy first minister predicts during a referendum campaign visit to the islands.

item.title: Swimming hero plea to find young fan
item.description: Scottish Commonwealth swimming champion Ross Murdoch appeals for help in finding a boy who wrote to him after his triumph at the 2014 Glasgow Games.

item.title: Man 'crushed between two vehicles'
item.description: A 57-year-old man dies at a commercial premises in Doagh, County Antrim.

item.title: Teen stabbing accused 'volatile'
item.description: A 15-year-old boy appears before a youth court in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, after a 14-year-old was stabbed in the stomach.

item.title: Arrest after children in house fire
item.description: A woman is arrested after a suspected arson attack on a house near Wrexham after two children were rescued from the burning building.

item.title: Wales to host investment conference
item.description: Wales will host an international investment conference after the Nato summit, UK Business Secretary Vince Cable announces.

item.title: South Sudan UN helicopter 'not shot'
item.description: Rebels in South Sudan deny an allegation that they shot down a UN helicopter, which crashed near the oil hub of Bentiu, killing three crew.

item.title: Lessing's library donated to Zimbabwe
item.description: More than 3,000 books from author Doris Lessing's collection have been given to Zimbabwe after her death.

item.title: Afghan election audit suspended
item.description: Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah withdraws observers from an audit of votes, citing concerns over fraud.

item.title: Japan PM marks war criminal ceremony
item.description: Japanese PM Shinzo Abe sent a message to a ceremony honouring war criminals, official confirm, amid strained ties with China and South Korea.

item.title: Germany to fight 'benefit tourism'
item.description: The German government announced proposals to tackle alleged abuses of the benefits system by migrants from elsewhere in the European Union.

item.title: Peru seizes cocaine hidden in coal
item.description: Peruvian police say they have found a stash a 3.3-tonnes stash of cocaine hidden in a consignment of coal that was bound for Europe.

item.title: Policemen jailed over Ecuador revolt
item.description: Six Ecuadorean police officers who took part in a 2010 mutiny are sentenced to 12 years in jail for trying to assassinate President Rafael Correa.

item.title: Brazil holds TV election debate
item.description: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff takes part in the first televised candidates' debate of the election campaign, defending her social programmes.

item.title: Gazans return home as truce holds
item.description: Thousands of Palestinians begin to return to their homes as an open-ended ceasefire between Israel and militants in Gaza appears to hold.

item.title: American 'fighter' dies in Syria battle
item.description: An American man, believed to be fighting alongside militants in Syria, has been killed, the White House has confirmed.

item.title: Lockheed Martin in space junk deal
item.description: US defence giant Lockheed Martin is teaming up with an Australian technology firm to track space debris that can damage multi-billion dollar satellites.

item.title: US schools to have non-white majority
item.description: White pupils in state schools in the United States are set to be a minority for the first time when schools return for the new term.

item.title: Day in pictures: 14 August 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 14 August

item.title: In pictures: Lauren Bacall
item.description: Life and career of US actress Lauren Bacall

item.title: In pictures: The Maliki years
item.description: Charting career of Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri Maliki

item.title: In pictures: Robin Williams
item.description: Career of actor and comedian in pictures

item.title: Day in pictures: 13 August 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 13 August

item.title: In pictures: Framing Hope
item.description: A new exhibition of photos by Jillian Edelstein

item.title: In pictures: Exodus of Yazidis
item.description: Yazidi refugees fleeing violence from Islamic State militants

item.title: Day in pictures: 12 August 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 12 August

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Israel's response to rocket attacks must be "proportionate", insists a minister.

item.title: VIDEO: US girl shoots gun tutor dead
item.description: CONTAINS DISTURBING IMAGES: A nine-year-old girl in the US has accidentally killed her shooting instructor while being shown how to use a high-powered automatic weapon.

item.title: VIDEO: Eighty years married and still in love
item.description: A couple who met in 1928 are celebrating their 80th wedding anniversary today and tell the BBC why they're still in love.

item.title: VIDEO: Taps run dry amid California drought
item.description: California has been hit by its worst drought in a century and many say the problem is only going to get worse.

item.title: VIDEO: Rotherham abuse: Police head will not quit
item.description: South Yorkshire Police Commissioner Shaun Wright says he took his responsibilities very seriously, but will not stand down.

item.title: VIDEO: 'No end in sight to Ukraine fighting'
item.description: A group of Russian soldiers captured in eastern Ukraine crossed the border "by accident", Russian military sources are quoted as saying.

item.title: VIDEO: What goes into a fake cigarette?
item.description: The BBC's Tom Brown finds out what is in a fake cigarette

item.title: VIDEO: Stars review Bush's comeback concert
item.description: Gemma Arterton and Anna Calvi gave BBC Newsnight their take on Kate Bush's comeback concert.

item.title: VIDEO: Helicopters buried in fire-drill foam
item.description: A number of Black Hawk helicopters were left covered in foam after a fire drill went wrong at a US military base in Oklahoma.

item.title: The parenting lessons to be taken from movies
item.description: Should anybody take a parenting tip from a movie?

item.title: How was Kate Bush's comeback?
item.description: Did Kate Bush's comeback concert wow her fans?

item.title: The etiquette of reclining seats on flights
item.description: When is it acceptable to recline your seat on flights?

item.title: Zara's 'Holocaust uniform' and other clothing errors
item.description: Clothes firm sorry over 'Holocaust T-shirt'

item.title: Sniffing out the allergy epidemic
item.description: Why so many of us are developing allergies

item.title: When Chinese children forget how to write
item.description: When China's children forget how to write

item.title: What Commons Clerk row is all about
item.description: What is row over new House of Commons Clerk about?

item.title: The Spanish mayor and the bra protest
item.description: Spanish mayor's rape comment prompts resignation calls

item.title: When we look, we find
item.description: When we look for sexual abuse, we find it

item.title: Will the EU get a dream team?
item.description: Women are now frontrunners in tense EU jobs race

item.title: Analysis: The Prevent strategy and its problems
item.description: UK's Prevent strategy remains deeply controversial
